trial_identification.studytitle: Brief Interventions for substance use and mental health symptoms in primary care
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Brief interventions versus self help for young people with substance use and mental health problems

interventions.interventions: 2 (1 hour) sessions of brief motivational interviewing (consisting of assessment feedback, information, motivational interviewing to increase motivation/confidence to make a change) delivered by a clinical psychologist within a one month time period
interventions.comparator: 1 (1 hour) session assessment feedback/information only control delivered by a clinical psychologist

primaryOutcome.outcome: Reduction in the frequency/quantity of alcohol and cannabis use in the past 4 weeks measured using the timeline followback procedure.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, one, three and six months follow up

primaryOutcome.outcome: Reduction in level of psychological distress in the past month measured on the Kessler 10 scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, one, three and six months follow up

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Improved motivation to make a change in alcohol/cannabis use, social and occupational functioning
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, one, three and six months follow up

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Kessler 10 score of greater to or equal to 17 At least weekly cannabis use and/or consumed alcohol above pre-2009 Australian national drinking guidelines (> 14 standard drinking units (SDUs) containing 10 grams of ethanol per week) in the last month

trial_design.concealment: Once infomed consent is obtained by the researcher participants will be randomly allocated to treatment group using a computer generated block randomisation technique

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This RCT compares the efficacy of a 2 session enhanced BMI (Quik Fix) compared to assessment/information (AI/F) only control, among young people with cannabis/alcohol use and high levels of psychological distress. It was hypothesized that Quik Fix would result in significantly larger reductions on the primary outcome variables of psychological distress and alcohol/cannabis use. It was also hypothesized that Quik Fix would result in significantly larger improvements on the secondary outcome variables of motivation to change alcohol/drug use, the severity of mental health symptoms and alcohol/cannabis use and functioning.
